bestBHT.bht: Father, I wholeheartedly acknowledge and thank You for the justice of Your ways. Your mysterious arrangements bring condemnation to the prideful and salvation to the humble and childlike. It is through a simple and teachable spirit that these truths are revealed, while the wise and clever of this world remain blind to them. Even in the rejection of Your message, it is the pride of their hearts that hinders understanding, displaying the brilliance of Your truth. May we, as forgiven sinners, listen and learn from You, wholly dependent on Your grace.

Henry Alford: I confess to Thee, ‘I recognize the justice of Thy doings;’ viz. in the words Even so, Father, &c.
[God's] mysterious arrangements, by which the sinner is condemned in his pride and unbelief, the humble and childlike saved, and God justified.
These are ‘revealed’ to those who can in a simple and teachable spirit, as babes, obey the invitation in vv. 28–30, but ‘hidden’ from the wise and clever of this world.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Yes; but there is a brighter side to the picture; even in those who have rejected the message of eternal life, it is the pride of their own hearts only which has blinded them, and the glory of the truth does but the more appear in their inability to receive it.

I assent to thee. But this is not strong enough. The idea of 'full' or 'cordial' concurrence is conveyed by the preposition. The thing expressed is adoring acquiescence, holy satisfaction with that law of the divine procedure about to be mentioned.

Because it is not for the offending and revolted to speak or to speculate, but to listen to Him from whom we have broken loose, that we may learn whether there be any recovery for us at all and if there be, on what principles—of what nature—to what ends.
Marvin Vincent: I thank [εξομολογουμαι]. Compare Matthew 3:6, of confessing sins. Lit., I confess. I recognize the justice and wisdom of thy doings."

Prudent [συνετων]. Rev., understanding; Wyc., wary. From the verb sunihmi, to bring together, and denoting that peculiarity of mind which brings the simple features of an object into a whole. Hence comprehension, insight.
Wise [σοφων] and understanding are often joined, as here. The general distinction is between productive and reflective wisdom, but the distinction is not always recognized by the writer.
John Calvin: Let it be observed, also, that the discourse is addressed to the Father, and consequently is marked by greater energy than if he had spoken to his disciples.
It was on their behalf, no doubt, and for their sake, that he gave thanks to the Father, that they might not be displeased with the low and mean aspect of his Church.
True, humble persons have Christ for their master, and the first lesson of faith is, Let no man presume on his wisdom.
Philip Schaff: I fully confess, thankfully acknowledge the justice of thy doings.
Those most learned and sagacious in all earthly things often cannot understand the simplest truths of Christianity.
Those despised by the world, because often ignorant of what it values, or considered 'babes,' because they believe like little children what their Heavenly Father reveals to them.
Archibald T. Robertson: It is usual to call this golden utterance a prayer, but it is at once prayer, praise, and self-communing in a devout spirit."
The only satisfying explanation lies in the fact that Jesus did have this strain of teaching that is preserved in John's Gospel.
Jesus praises the Father 'not that the σοφο were ignorant, but that the νηπιο knew'.
John Gill: I thank thee, 0 Father, Lord of heaven and earth."
The things of the Gospel are hidden from them" (referring to the wise and prudent).
To such souls God reveals the covenant of his grace, Christ, and all the blessings of grace in him, the mysteries of the Gospel, and the unseen glories of another world.
John Wesley: I thank thee - That is, I acknowledge and joyfully adore the justice and mercy of thy dispensations..."

Because thou hast hid - That is, because thou hast suffered these things to be hid from men, who are in other respects wise and prudent, while thou hast discovered them to those of the weakest understanding...
...to them who are only wise to Godward.

bhtAttempts.bht:
I humbly acknowledge and recognize the justice of Your ways, Father. It is through Your mysterious plans that the sinner's pride and unbelief are condemned, while the humble and childlike are saved, thus justifying Your actions. These revelations are made known to those who approach You with a simple and teachable spirit, while they remain hidden from the wise and clever of this world. Indeed, even those who reject the message of eternal life are merely blinded by the pride in their hearts, which only serves to highlight the glory of the truth they are unable to receive. Let us listen to You, O Lord, rather than speculate or speak, that we may understand if there is any hope for us in Your plan.  

Note: This response is 90 words long, exceeding the specified word limit.

Father, I confess and recognize the justice of Your ways. Your mysterious arrangements condemn the prideful and unbelieving, while saving the humble and childlike. These truths are revealed to those who approach You with a simple and teachable spirit. Even those who reject Your message only do so because their pride blinds them, magnifying the glory of the truth they cannot receive. Let us listen and learn from You, for we have broken loose from You and need to discover if there is any recovery for us.

I acknowledge and thank You, Father, for the justice of Your ways. Your mysterious arrangements reveal that the humble and childlike are saved, while the wise and clever are unable to see the truth. It is not for us to speculate or speak, but to listen and learn from You. By recognizing our own limitations, we can grasp the principles and ends of Your plan for us. Let us approach You with a simple and teachable spirit, eager to receive Your wisdom and grace.

Father, I confess to You my recognition of the justice in Your actions. Your mysterious arrangements ensure that the prideful and unbelieving are condemned while the humble and childlike are saved. These truths are revealed to those with a simple and teachable spirit, while they remain hidden from the worldly wise. Even those who reject Your message do so out of their own pride, further showcasing the glory of Your truth. Let us set aside our own speculations and humbly listen and learn from You.

Father, I wholeheartedly acknowledge and thank You for the justice of Your ways. Your mysterious arrangements bring condemnation to the prideful and salvation to the humble and childlike. It is through a simple and teachable spirit that these truths are revealed, while the wise and clever of this world remain blind to them. Even in the rejection of Your message, it is the pride of their hearts that hinders understanding, displaying the brilliance of Your truth. May we, as forgiven sinners, listen and learn from You, wholly dependent on Your grace.
